author: By Ed Shanahan
title: A trail of clues in online rants, a rented van and a fireworks purchase.
description: The New York Police Department fanned across the city early Wednesday searching for clues and offered a $50,000 reward for information that leads to the arrest of the gunman in the Brooklyn subway shooting.
content: The New York Police Department fanned across the five boroughs early Wednesday searching for clues and offered a $50,000 reward for information that leads to the arrest of the gunman who fired 33 shots on a rush-hour subway train in Brooklyn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael LaForgia, Ana Ley and Michael Rothfeld
title: Cameras at the station where the subway shooting occurred were flagged as faulty days earlier.
description: Maintenance workers on Sunday inspected the cameras at the 36th Street station in Brooklyn, where a gunman wounded 10 and left 13 injured, and discovered a connection problem.
content: A subway security camera system that failed in a Brooklyn station where a gunman committed a mass shooting on Tuesday had been flagged by New York City Transit workers as malfunctioning two days earlier, transit officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Spencer Bokat-Lindell
title: Is a Recession the Only Way to Stop Inflation?
description: Raising interest rates will pour cold water on an economy many believe is overheated — but at the risk of triggering a downturn.
content: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Wednesdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Rikki Novetsky, Stella Tan, Clare Toeniskoetter, Patricia Willens, Mike Benoist, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: The Next Phase of the War in Ukraine
description: Moscow has narrowed its goals. What does that tell us about Russia’s military?
content: After a disastrous defeat in northern Ukraine, Russia has begun a high-stakes battle for the east, while Western allies arm Ukrainian fighters determined to stave off the attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Roach
title: Why You Should Plant a Garden That’s Wasp Friendly
description: Those wasps you hate? They’re the best organic pest control around. Here’s how to keep them happy (and avoid getting stung).
content: Attention, spheksophobes: Wasps just want to help.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Georgia’s 2018 Rematch, in a Courtroom
description: A trial is underway to determine whether Georgia’s handling of the 2018 election for governor was discriminatory, in a case brought by Stacey Abrams’s voting rights group.
content: The 2018 race for governor in Georgia ended in a bitter dispute between Brian Kemp, a Republican who was serving as secretary of state at the time, and Stacey Abrams, the Democratic challenger who accused the state of voter suppression.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: As Mamet Returns to Broadway, His Claims on Pedophilia Get Spotlight
description: The playwright fueled outrage with his claim on Fox News that teachers were “inclined” to pedophilia as he promoted a new book that decries “the Left’s anti-Trump psychosis.”
content: David Mamet’s latest character describes an airplane pilot who gets lost because his map is incomplete. “The pilot’s answer to the question ‘where am I?’ lies not on the map, but out the windscreen,” says the character, speaking in the everyday language set to staccato rhythm that has come to be known as Mametspeak. “That’s where he is.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Could California Switch to Permanent Daylight Saving Time?
description: Lawmakers in the Golden State and elsewhere are considering eliminating the biannual time switch.
content: In November 2018, Californians overwhelmingly approved a ballot measure that promised to do away with the twice-a-year changing of the clocks that many of us have come to revile. Daylight saving time, it seemed, would soon be a thing of the past.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Johnson’s Cabinet Backs Him After ‘Partygate’ Fine
description: The support from the British prime minister’s party means he can likely ride out the immediate storm, but his troubles are not over, experts say.
content: LONDON — One said that Prime Minister Boris Johnson had “taken responsibility,” another that he had “apologized unreservedly,” while a third appealed to Britons to look at the bigger picture and cut some slack to a politician who was “delivering for Britain.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $2.2 Million Homes in Tennessee, Florida and New York
description: A Nashville Victorian owned by an HGTV host, a Key West house where the writer John Dos Passos once lived, and a rustic log cabin in East Durham.
content: The owner of this house, Kortney Wilson, is also the listing agent, as well as the host of “Masters of Flip” and “Music City Fix,” HGTV shows focused on restoring historic homes in Nashville. This house, in the Lockeland Springs neighborhood, is a mix of old and new, with an open kitchen, exposed-brick walls and several original fireplaces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Miller
title: Six Outs From a Perfect Game, Kershaw’s Day Was Done
description: Not wanting to risk injuring his aging ace, Manager Dave Roberts pulled Clayton Kershaw. He had thrown only 80 pitches.
content: Clayton Kershaw has won three National League Cy Young Awards, one N.L. Most Valuable Player Award and a World Series. He has thrown a no-hitter and compiled a near-certain Hall of Fame résumé.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Ruttenberg
title: Only Gilbert Gottfried Could Be So Dirty and So Heartbreaking
description: He turned shocking jokes and “Howard Stern” appearances into something of an art form, one he practiced even when the occasion was a school fund-raiser.
content: Some comedians unfurl yarns in the unhurried mode of a jam band, others display the taut rhythms of pop or hip-hop. Gilbert Gottfried, who came of age in a fraught New York City and died on Tuesday at 67, always felt like punk in the classic CBGB mold: nervy, artful, deceivingly intelligent, a tad unhinged, and blissfully — beautifully — obnoxious.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Concepción de León
title: ‘Women of the White Buffalo’ Review: Speaking Out on the Reservation
description: This documentary sheds light on the destitute conditions in two South Dakota reservations through the stories of the communities’ women.
content: The documentary “Women of the White Buffalo” explores the myriad challenges experienced by Indigenous people on reservations, as well as the historical roots of these social maladies. The story is told through Lakota women living on the Pine Ridge and Rosebud Indian reservations in South Dakota, where rampant alcoholism, drug addiction, poverty and violence threaten the Lakotas’ way of life and future generations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: William G. Hamilton, Doctor to Dancers, Is Dead at 90
description: Invited by George Balanchine to be the in-house orthopedic surgeon at City Ballet in New York, he laid the groundwork for the field of dance medicine.
content: Dr. William G. Hamilton, who as the attending orthopedic surgeon for New York City Ballet spent more than 40 years fixing bone spurs, tendinitis, bursitis, torn ligaments and what he called “the Nutcracker Fracture,” died on March 29 at his home in Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y. He was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Perri Klass, M.D
title: Returning to Florence With ‘the World’s Most Opinionated Guide’
description: After two years, travel is at last opening up — the perfect time to look at this classic Tuscan destination with new, less jaded eyes. For a fresh perspective, let the critic and novelist Mary McCarthy be your guide.
content: “Almost nobody comes to see Donatello’s ‘David’ in the Bargello, the first nude statue of the Renaissance,” lamented Mary McCarthy in 1959 in “The Stones of Florence,” a masterpiece of American travel writing. A famously contrarian critic, she believed that Michelangelo’s David was overvalued, and, writing for a postwar generation of American travelers, wanted them to appreciate an earlier sculptural tradition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Detrick
title: Chloë Sevigny and Cory Kennedy Honor the Downtown Poets
description: The Poetry Project held an eclectic gala in the East Village.
content: Phantoms from a vanishing downtown were summoned to St. Mark’s Church in-the-Bowery last Friday for the Poetry Project’s 55th anniversary gala. The organization is an enduring harborage for New York City poets, and the event brought several generations of the creative community under one steeple to celebrate the spoken word.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Simmons
title: Frank James was quiet and gruff, his neighbors in Milwaukee said.
description: A neighbor of Frank R. James, the suspect in Tuesday’s mass shooting on a subway train in Brooklyn and who is now in custody, said in an interview that Mr. James was gruff and standoffish, and once confronted her over a key left in her apartment door.
content: A neighbor of Frank R. James, the suspect in Tuesday’s mass shooting on a subway train in Brooklyn and who is now in custody, said in an interview that Mr. James was gruff and standoffish, and once confronted her over a key left in her apartment door.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: Videos Show Police Officer Fatally Shooting Black Man in Michigan
description: Patrick Lyoya, 26, was killed by a Grand Rapids police officer last week during a traffic stop. Activists said the shooting followed years of unheeded calls for changes to the police force.
content: The police in Grand Rapids, Mich., released videos on Wednesday showing a white officer fatally shooting Patrick Lyoya, a 26-year-old Black man, after a struggle during a traffic stop last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein and Nicole Hong
title: As pandemic-era remote work becomes permanent, Manhattan’s economy faces an uncertain future.
description: The list of companies permanently changing the way they work keeps growing longer and, for those in New York City, the five-day-a-week trek into Manhattan is becoming a fading corporate practice — with enormous consequences for the city, whose economy is especially dependent on filling its forests of office towers.
content: The list of companies permanently changing the way they work keeps growing longer and, for those in New York City, the five-day-a-week trek into Manhattan is becoming a fading corporate practice — with enormous consequences for the city, whose economy is especially dependent on filling its forests of office towers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich, Rebecca Davis O'Brien, Chelsia Rose Marcius and Ed Shanahan
title: The shooting suspect left troubling videos online.
description: He has addresses in Wisconsin and Philadelphia.
content: The suspect in Tuesday’s subway attack in Brooklyn appears to have posted dozens of videos on social media in recent years — lengthy rants in which he expressed a range of harshly bigoted views and, more recently, criticized the policies of New York City’s mayor, Eric Adams.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Rapold
title: ‘Father Stu’ Review: Screwball Salvation
description: Mark Wahlberg throws himself into the real-life story of an oddball priest in Rosalind Ross’s debut feature.
content: Mark Wahlberg dials himself up to 11 in “Father Stu,” a never-say-die story of religious redemption and all-American hustle. Wahlberg’s career is full of characters who totally believe in their own game, and here, he throws himself into the oddball role of Stuart Long — a Montana boxer turned beloved priest who developed a degenerative muscle disease and died at 50.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: Free Advice for Putin: ‘Make Peace, You Fool’
description: John Arquilla explains how Ukrainians have adopted the three new rules of war.
content: As Vladimir Putin embarks on his Plan B — a massive military operation to try to grab at least a small bite of eastern Ukraine to justify his misbegotten war — I thought: Who could give him the best advice right now? I settled on one of America’s premier teachers of grand strategy, John Arquilla, who recently retired as a distinguished professor of defense analysis at the U.S. Naval Postgraduate School. When I called Arquilla and asked him what he’d tell Putin today, he didn’t hesitate: “I would say, ‘Make peace, you fool.’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: Alyssa Nakken Adds Yet Another First by Coaching First Base
description: The San Francisco Giants coach became the first woman to take an on-field role in a Major League Baseball game. “This is my job,” she said.
content: It was an unusual scene at Oracle Park in San Francisco on Tuesday. The Giants’ first-base coach was ejected in the third inning, and after his replacement took the field, Eric Hosmer, the first baseman for the San Diego Padres, came over to shake her hand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane O'Neill
title: Sexy Lingerie for Men Is Here
description: Lacy thongs and sheer undergarments designed for men’s bodies are shaking up the traditional lingerie market.
content: As a multidisciplinary artist who explores Black and queer identity, LaQuann Dawson, 27, often takes self-portraits from his home and studio in Brooklyn wearing women’s lingerie. But he found that the bodysuits and bottoms didn’t fit well.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: New Zealand welcomes vaccinated tourists from Australia and relaxes more policies.
description: The latest steps toward reopening are being taken in a country that has maintained some of the strictest coronavirus precautions in the world.
content: Thousands of tourists and international students arrived in New Zealand from Australia on Wednesday, some to reunite with family and friends, in a further sign of reopening in countries that have maintained some of the world’s strictest coronavirus restrictions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Kim
title: This Cake Gives You a Moment of Warmth in the Middle of the Day
description: Chamomile cake is just right at teatime, an excuse to give yourself and friends an hour to sit down and linger.
content: When I was in graduate school, nearly a decade ago, I bought a cheap porcelain teapot that I still use today. It has faux-gold lining, with edges that gleam, and a pink-and-jade rosebud print across its surface. A halo of teal encircles the lid, which comes off with a clinking sound. If a cherub were a teapot, then this would be it. It’s priceless to me and dutifully sturdy, having stayed by my side across multiple New York City apartments and afternoon teatimes with friends.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alison Gregor
title: House Hunting in Grenada: A Better ‘Beach Shack’ on the Caribbean Coast
description: ‘There has been no tourism for almost two years’ in Grenada, agents say, leading to more opportunities for domestic buyers and savvy investors.
content: This two-bedroom farm-style house offers Atlantic Ocean and Caribbean Sea views from a bluff above a white sandy beach on the southeast coast of Carriacou, an island in Grenada.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: Trump Poses a Test Democracy Is Failing
description: Ordinary voters are supposed to punish authoritarians by removing them from office. Intensifying partisanship is threatening that mechanism.
content: Ordinary citizens play a critical role in maintaining democracy. They refuse to re-elect — at least in theory — politicians who abuse their power, break the rules and reject the outcome of elections they lose. How is it, then, that Donald Trump, who has defied these basic presumptions, stands a reasonable chance of winning a second term in 2024?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chelsia Rose Marcius, Troy Closson and Sean Piccoli
title: Investigators conducted a wide sweep for the suspect before his capture.
description: Hundreds of detectives from the New York City Police Department and members of other law enforcement agencies on Wednesday had joined a sweeping search for the suspect in the Brooklyn subway attack.
content: Hundreds of detectives from the New York City Police Department and members of other law enforcement agencies on Wednesday had joined a sweeping search for the suspect in the Brooklyn subway attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman and Michael Gold
title: ‘We got him’: The police captured the gunman after a tip from the public.
description: New York City police officers on Wednesday apprehended the man who they believed opened fire on a Brooklyn subway train the previous day, officials said.
content: New York City police officers on Wednesday apprehended the man who they believed opened fire on a Brooklyn subway train the previous day, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Cappelle
title: Bringing Consent to Ballet, One Intimacy Workshop at a Time
description: Touch is a requirement of a dancer’s job. Now when choreography involves simulated sex or violence, some companies are bringing in intimacy directors.
content: GLASGOW — The intensity of the choreography left visible marks on Bethany Kingsley-Garner’s body. On a recent afternoon in the Glasgow studios of Scottish Ballet, she was running through an upsetting scene in Kenneth MacMillan’s 1978 ballet “Mayerling.” Her character, Stephanie, is violently assaulted on her wedding night by her husband, Crown Prince Rudolf. As she was grabbed, thrown and lifted, Kingsley-Garner’s back, visible through a cutout in her leotard, grew increasingly red from the rough — sometimes audibly so — skin-to-skin contact.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Is Investing in Defense Contractors Actually Immoral?
description: Without the help of weapons from companies like Lockheed Martin, all of Ukraine might have been conquered by now.
content: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has made a lot of us into armchair warriors. Even people who once looked askance at defense contractors are suddenly cheering on the success of the companies’ deadly wares, including Javelin anti-tank missiles, Stinger antiaircraft missiles and Switchblade drones, which “loiter” above a target before zooming in for the kill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Wong
title: Teachers in Sunset Park kept students calm and answered tough questions during lockdown.
description: For Shahana Ghosh, a first-grade teacher at P.S. 24 in Sunset Park, just two blocks from the subway station where Tuesday’s shooting took place, the day began like any other.
content: For Shahana Ghosh, a first-grade teacher at P.S. 24 in Sunset Park, just two blocks from the subway station where Tuesday’s shooting took place, the day began like any other.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Yellen Calls on China to Push Russia to End Ukraine War.
description: The Treasury secretary told the Atlantic Council that the U.S. would press ahead with sanctions.
content: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen urged China on Wednesday to persuade Russia to end its war in Ukraine and warned that staying on the sidelines could jeopardize China’s standing in the global economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica Ackerberg
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Photographing the Reality of War’
description: In this lesson, students will learn about a New York Times photojournalist’s approach to bearing witness to the war in Ukraine.
content: Featured Article: “Photographing the Reality of War” by Emmett Lindner
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Argument'
title: The Dangerous Lesson Viktor Orban Taught Republicans
description: Bret Stephens and Zack Beauchamp debate the biggest challenges threatening liberalism in America and beyond.
content: President Biden has described the world as being in a “battle between democracy and autocracy.” And Prime Minister Viktor Orban’s recent victory in Hungary, especially, has marked it as a country in pursuit of what Orban calls an “illiberal democracy.” So what has happened to liberalism, and why is it so deeply challenged today?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Guerrero’s Three Homers Power Blue Jays Past Yankees
description: Toronto has taken two of three games against their division rival. The Mets, meanwhile, slugged their way past the Phillies.
content: Vladimir Guerrero Jr. shook off a bloody gash on his right ring finger to hit three home runs against the rival Yankees, including two off ace Gerrit Cole, and the Toronto Blue Jays beat New York, 6-4, Wednesday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Scrambling in Play-In, Nets Offer Glimpse of What They Can Be
description: For three quarters, the Nets again showed their best side. A matchup against the Celtics in the playoffs will require a more complete effort.
content: For much of their N.B.A. play-in game against the Cleveland Cavaliers on Tuesday night, the Nets looked like the fearsome team that many observers had long said lay hidden behind their mediocre record. Kevin Durant was magnificent. Kyrie Irving didn’t miss a shot until the fourth quarter. Multiple teammates made significant contributions well above what was usually expected of them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Zornosa
title: National Endowment for the Humanities Announces $33.17 Million in Grants
description: In New York, the Tenement Museum, Women Make Movies, UnionDocs, LaGuardia Community College and more will receive funding.
content: A book about Motown Productions, the film and television arm of the legendary Motown Records; preservation of the traditional language and lifestyle of Yup’ik and Cup’ik Alaskan Native people; and research on how communities — and insurance companies — in Bermuda understand risk caused by rising sea levels and climate change are among the 245 projects across the country that are receiving new grants from the National Endowment for the Humanities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: circumnavigate
description: This word has appeared in 16 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word circumnavigate has appeared in 16 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Jan. 20 in “She Flew Around the World in 155 Days. She’s Only 19.” by Mike Ives:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan and Michael Owens
title: N.F.L. Players Try a Different Training Camp: The Broadcast Booth
description: N.F.L. broadcasters netted massive contracts this off-season. A league-organized boot camp prepares the players who want to follow their path.
content: INGLEWOOD, Calif. — Sebastian Joseph-Day, a former defensive tackle for the Los Angeles Rams, scrunched his face as he recognized his mistake.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Prevost
title: Woodbridge, Conn.: A Rural Enclave Close to New Haven
description: This ‘suburban community in a country setting’ is just a 20-minute commute from Yale University, other educational institutions and a number of biotech companies.
content: Woodbridge, Conn., a quiet suburb on New Haven’s western edge, is a place where privacy comes easily. Most of the residential lots in town are at least an acre and a half, and multifamily housing is almost nonexistent. More than a quarter of the town’s land area is protected open space. And what little commercial activity is permitted is contained within the town’s southeastern corner, adjacent to the Merritt Parkway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Your Thursday Briefing: Finland and Sweden May Join NATO
description: Plus the world has now surpassed 500 million known Covid cases.
content: Finland and Sweden are considering whether to apply for NATO membership in the coming weeks and are widely expected to join, underscoring how the invasion of Ukraine has backfired for President Vladimir Putin of Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: Subway service resumes at 36th Street after police finish investigation.
description: As of Wednesday morning, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said it was running full service across the entire subway system.
content: Subway service resumed at the 36th Street station in Brooklyn after the New York Police Department concluded their investigation there into Tuesday’s mass shooting, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said early Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Weaker oil demand, especially in China, might ease supply crunch caused by sanctions.
description: The International Energy Agency foresees slower growth in demand for oil, caused by high prices and economic slowdowns.
content: The International Energy Agency said Wednesday that Covid lockdowns in China were likely to sharply cut the growth in demand for oil in that country, potentially easing a supply crunch caused by sanctions on Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Markham Heid
title: Why Experts Can’t Seem to Agree on Boosters
description: How can scientists look at the same evidence and come to such different conclusions?
content: Should you get another Covid booster shot?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Severe Storms Are Again Expected Across the Midwest and the South
description: Meteorologists said thunderstorms could produce damaging winds, large hail and tornadoes in the Midwest and the Mississippi Valley, a day after tornadoes injured nearly two dozen people in Texas.
content: A line of severe thunderstorms was expected to sweep across parts of the Midwest and the Mississippi Valley on Wednesday, raising the risk of tornadoes, flash floods and damaging winds, meteorologists said. The unsettling forecast comes a day after tornadoes ripped through Texas, injuring nearly two dozen people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney
title: Singing, and Signing, Beethoven’s ‘Fidelio’ in Los Angeles
description: The Los Angeles Philharmonic and Deaf West Theater are working on an innovative production conceived for both hearing and deaf operagoers.
content: LOS ANGELES — DJ Kurs has been the artistic director of the Deaf West Theater, a theater company created here by deaf actors, for the past 10 years. But he had never seen the Los Angeles Philharmonic or been to the Walt Disney Concert Hall, its renowned home, even though he grew up in Southern California.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger and Johanna Lemola
title: Despite Russian Warnings, Finland and Sweden Draw Closer to NATO
description: The invasion of Ukraine has heightened security fears, pushing even formally nonaligned countries toward the Western alliance.
content: BRUSSELS — Even before his invasion of Ukraine, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia had warned Sweden and Finland of “retaliation” should they join NATO. It was, after all, Ukraine’s desire to join the alliance that he cited time and again as provocation for his war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Schweber and Ashley Wong
title: ‘When you live in New York City, you’ve got to recover’: At the 36th Street station, more officers and plenty of commuters.
description: The platform was crowded and the mood was somber Wednesday morning as police officers patrolled the 36th Street station in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, about 24 hours after a gunman shot 10 people inside a train approaching the station.
content: The platform was crowded and the mood was somber Wednesday morning as police officers patrolled the 36th Street station in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, about 24 hours after a gunman shot 10 people inside a train approaching the station.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi, Erin Griffith and Kate Conger
title: U.S. tech companies are stepping up office perks, hoping to make employees feel happier about returning.
description: When Google employees returned to their mostly empty offices this month, they were told to relax. Office time should be “not only productive but also fun.” Explore the place a little. Don’t book back-to-back meetings.
content: When Google employees returned to their mostly empty offices this month, they were told to relax. Office time should be “not only productive but also fun.” Explore the place a little. Don’t book back-to-back meetings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Etsy and the Sameness of Internet Fights
description: How much should the middleman get?
content: This week, thousands of people who sell goods on Etsy are going on strike to protest the company’s climbing fees. And what seems to be a fight over a small corner of the internet is really one of the most enduring battles over our digital world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson, Jonah E. Bromwich and Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: The suspect in the subway shooting has been arrested, officials say.
description: The suspect, Frank R. James, was apprehended in the East Village, according to law enforcement officials.
content: Frank R. James, who law enforcement officials say perpetrated the worst attack on New York’s subway system in years, was taken into custody Wednesday, more than 24 hours into an expansive search that began after at least 10 people were shot at a Brooklyn train station.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: California Woman Admits Faking Her Abduction, Prosecutors Say
description: Sherri Papini’s 2016 disappearance prompted a three-week search. This week, she admitted she made it up and agreed to a plea bargain, the authorities said.
content: A California woman whose disappearance in 2016 prompted an intense, weekslong search has accepted a plea bargain, admitting that she made up the story she gave the authorities about being abducted, beaten and leashed to a pole in a closet, prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Stephen Colbert Scoffs at John Eastman’s Obsession With the Election
description: “Our ex-president isn’t allowed a do-over just because he didn’t like the result the first time. That’s how you get an Eric,” Colbert joked.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim
title: President Biden accuses Russia of committing genocide in Ukraine.
description: It was the first time the president has used the term to describe the Russia’s war. He emphasized it was a personal view, not a legal determination.
content: President Biden on Tuesday for the first time accused Russia’s president, Vladimir V. Putin, of perpetrating genocide on the Ukrainian people, but emphasized that was his personal view, not a legal determination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: ‘We’re All Going to the World’s Fair’ Review: Is It Horror, or Just Ennui?
description: In Jane Schoenbrun’s first feature, a teenager finds terror and distraction in a multiplayer online game.
content: Way back in the 1965, Susan Sontag observed that “we live under continual threat of two equally fearful, but seemingly opposed, destinies: unremitting banality and inconceivable terror.” Still true, but with the added wrinkle that nowadays it can be hard to distinguish banality from terror.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Terrorism Trial Ends With Account of Aid Worker’s Enslavement
description: El Shafee Elsheikh was accused of being one of four British members of the Islamic State responsible for the torture and killing of Kayla Mueller and three others.
content: ALEXANDRIA, Va. — Federal prosecutors concluded their conspiracy and terrorism case against a British member of the Islamic State on Wednesday with a wrenching account of how an aid worker had been brutalized and sexually assaulted during a year and a half in captivity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: How to Make Sense of the New L.G.B.T.Q. Culture War
description: There is an enormous gap between what people are willing say in public and what they really think.
content: To understand the contours of the renewed culture wars over sex education, sexual orientation and gender identity, start with a Rorschach test.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Hoberman
title: ‘Mississippi Masala’: A Love Story Among the Displaced
description: In Mira Nair’s sweet, sexy film from 1991, an Indian American woman falls for a Black cleaner played charmingly, as ever, by Denzel Washington.
content: Mira Nair’s “Mississippi Masala” begins with a bit of family history that is also a history lesson — the expulsion of Uganda’s sizable South Asian population, ordered from the country by the military strongman Idi Amin in 1972.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Officials are seeking to instill confidence in New York City’s subway system.
description: The chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said on Wednesday that the goal is to “restore ridership and the functionality of New York.”
content: Officials appeared on morning TV shows and posted photos of themselves on trains on Wednesday as they attempted to instill confidence in New York City’s subway system a day after the attack at the 36th Street station in Brooklyn, which has heightened fears at a time when ridership remains low because of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Major Matisse Exhibition Coming to Philadelphia
description: “Matisse in the 1930s,” a new show devoted to that innovative decade of the painter’s work, is slated to open this fall at the Philadelphia Museum of Art.
content: In 1930, Albert Barnes, the art collector and founder of the Barnes Foundation, did something a bit audacious: He asked Henri Matisse, who was visiting the United States as a juror for the Carnegie International exhibition in Pittsburgh, to create an enormous painting. Matisse, then 60, had not completed any paintings during the previous year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times Magazine
title: Just Moved to New York? Got a Roommate Story?
description: The New York Times Magazine wants to hear from people who moved to New York City during the pandemic — and found themselves in unique housing situations.
content: Moving to New York City often means sharing a living space with strangers. They can become friends or lovers, our guides to the city, sometimes our rivals. Our roommates can come from very different backgrounds, or be at different stages in life, or work and socialize in different worlds from our own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia and Maria Varenikova
title: Pencil Cases and Air-Raid Sirens: School at War for Ukraine’s Children
description: The country’s teachers are doing their best to provide lessons for the millions of school-age children whose education has been interrupted.
content: KRAKOW, Poland — Across Ukraine, kindergartens have been bombed, elementary schools have been converted into shelters and in some cities like Mariupol, their grounds have even become makeshift graveyards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman
title: The N.Y.C. subway was struggling to rebound. Then the Brooklyn shooting happened.
description: The New York City subway was already struggling. A pandemic-fueled ridership plunge left the system facing a fiscal cliff. A rise in random attacks scared off passengers in droves. The shift to remote work that seems poised to outlive the coronavirus may mean ridership never fully recovers.
content: The New York City subway was already struggling. A pandemic-fueled ridership plunge left the system facing a fiscal cliff. A rise in random attacks scared off passengers in droves. The shift to remote work that seems poised to outlive the coronavirus may mean ridership never fully recovers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Manchester City Still Standing After Taking Atlético’s Best Shots
description: City, a team shaped by style, showed it was also skilled in the dark arts as it eliminated Atlético Madrid and moved a step closer to its first Champions League title.
content: MADRID — Many things happened at the Wanda Metropolitano in the final 10 or 20 minutes, the ones that seemed to stretch on and on, long past the final whistle, until they almost constituted another self-contained bonus game, a separate third installment of a scheduled two-part drama.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: What We Know About the Brooklyn Subway Shooting
description: The police have arrested a suspect, a 62-year-old man who has posted vitriolic rants on YouTube and criticized New York’s mayor.
content: A man who the police had identified as a suspect in the Brooklyn subway shooting, Frank R. James, was taken into custody on Wednesday, according law enforcement officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons and Jeffery C. Mays
title: Subway Attack Heightens Pressure on Mayor Adams to Combat Gun Violence
description: Mayor Eric Adams ran on a public safety message. He says crime is a national problem, but faces growing pressure to tackle it in New York City.
content: In his 10th and final media appearance of the morning, Mayor Eric Adams stuck to the day’s message: He can push to get guns off the streets and flood the subway with police officers, but there is only so much the city can do to stop someone who is determined to commit mayhem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivy Manners
title: What We Saw at New York Bridal Fashion Week
description: Last week, bridal designers showed collections in person for the first time in two years. These are the trends that emerged.
content: “There is greater appreciation and dedication to making this special day momentous after so many cancellations,” said Stephanie White, the founder and creative director of bridal line Odylyne the Ceremony.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Heinrich
title: 5 Ukrainian Art Accounts to Follow on Instagram Now
description: Artists continue to work, documenting the impact of events as they unfold to keep the world watching.
content: Social media give us responses to the Russian invasion of Ukraine almost instantly, but some of the most moving responses I’ve seen come from the young Ukrainian artists who’ve managed to make new work documenting events as they unfold.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: California Reveals Its Plan to Phase Out New Gas-Powered Cars by 2035
description: If adopted, the new measures would make a dent in the state’s greenhouse gas emissions and set the bar for the broader auto industry.
content: WASHINGTON — California on Wednesday made public an aggressive plan to mandate a steady increase in the sale of electric and zero-emissions vehicles, the first step in enacting a first-in-the-nation goal of banning new gasoline-powered cars by 2035.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Jerry Uelsmann, Surreal Image-Maker, Dies at 87
description: He did not believe that a photographer’s creativity ended with the click of the shutter; in his darkroom, he combined elements of multiple pictures to create something new.
content: Jerry Uelsmann, a photographer who ingeniously used darkroom techniques to manipulate his black-and-white pictures into surreal montages that anticipated by many years the digital image-editing revolutionized by Adobe Photoshop, died on April 4 in Gainesville, Fla. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Captured Ukrainian oligarch was a figure in the U.S. investigation into Russian electoral meddling.
description: Viktor Medvedchuk, a Ukrainian politician close to President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, was also a client of Paul Manafort, the Republican political consultant and Trump campaign chairman.
content: His name had surfaced as an influential figure in Ukraine with potential inside knowledge of Russian electoral meddling in the United States, though for years he had steadfastly denied it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: A Fed governor says the latest inflation data reaffirms the case for big rate increases.
description: The central bank is contemplating a half-point rate move in May. Christopher J. Waller, a Fed governor, said inflation data may justify big increases in months to come.
content: Christopher J. Waller, one of the Federal Reserve’s governors in Washington, said on Wednesday that recent economic data suggests that the central bank should raise interest rates by more than usual in May, and potentially in June and July as well.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter C. Baker
title: The Great Chicago Gas Giveaway and the Return of Stunt Philanthropy
description: Grand shows of largess may be back in style.
content: Recently, driving on the North Side of Chicago, I found myself stuck behind a line of cars long enough that I could not, at first, tell what was causing it. It was only minutes later, after I was able to switch lanes and pull ahead, that I saw the cars were waiting at a gas station. Had something in the news set off a flurry of panic buying? I turned on the radio and soon learned that the people I saw were not, in fact, buying fuel. They were hoping to get some free.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Russia’s stated aims in Ukraine.
content: In his first extended remarks about the war in almost a month, Vladimir Putin, Russia’s president, said that his country would persist in its invasion of Ukraine “until its full completion.” Peace talks with Ukraine had reached a “dead end,” he said, as he falsely described as “fake” evidence of Russian atrocities in the Kyiv suburb of Bucha. Follow the latest updates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: ‘You would think it’s a safe place’: A nurse recounts an attack on a Mariupol hospital.
description: The attack last month was among the first signs that Ukraine was facing a merciless war.
content: When a Russian missile strike hit a maternity hospital in the Ukrainian port city of Mariupol early last month, Elena Karas, a nurse, was on the third floor taking care of 13 premature babies, two of whom had been abandoned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen I. Vladeck
title: Roberts Has Lost Control of the Supreme Court
description: What did it take for him to finally speak out? He has joined the liberal justices in seeing an abuse of the shadow docket.
content: Last week the Supreme Court, by a 5-to-4 vote, put back into effect a Trump administration regulation that limited the ability of states to block projects that could pollute rivers and streams. The unsigned, unexplained order in Louisiana v. American Rivers came as part of a highly technical dispute over the scope of the Clean Water Act — and leaves for another day whether the regulation is a valid interpretation of that Nixon-era statute.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Have Fun Like It’s Your Job
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, April 13, 2022.
content: “What are you going to do next? Get Justin Bieber and then Katy Perry?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen
title: In Elden Ring, the Struggle Feels Real
description: The video game evokes the hardship and disappointment of the pandemic, but also the hope of human communion.
content: In the last two years, the pandemic has brought us many works of art that have tried to definitively capture humanity’s struggle. There was that movie with Leonardo DiCaprio turning pink as he shouts at the top of his lungs for people to look up at the comet hurtling toward Earth. It was so on the nose that it provoked little thought: Yes, we are divided, likely doomed. What of it?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni, Anna Schaverien and David F. Gallagher
title: Has U.S. Inflation Peaked?
description: Prices rose last month at the fastest pace in more than four decades. Some economists think inflation may be subsiding.
content: Inflation in the U.S. was running at 8.5 percent in the year to March, new data showed yesterday, the highest level in more than 40 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Ley and Anushka Patil
title: Problems with New York’s subway cameras date back years.
description: The lack of security camera footage from the 36th Street subway station has become a significant obstacle in efforts to detain the gunman in Tuesday’s attack, putting the Metropolitan Transportation Authority’s surveillance system under renewed scrutiny.
content: The lack of security camera footage from the 36th Street subway station has become a significant obstacle in efforts to detain the gunman in Tuesday’s attack, putting the Metropolitan Transportation Authority’s surveillance system under renewed scrutiny.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon
title: Death Toll in South Africa Floods Passes 306
description: The devastation fueled criticism that the government should have been better prepared for the weather after intense rain in 2017 and 2019.
content: JOHANNESBURG — The death toll from several days of punishing rain that drenched the city of Durban and the surrounding areas near South Africa’s east coast rose to more than 306 on Wednesday, prompting criticism from residents that the government had failed to prepare for what are now increasingly frequent storms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: Britain’s inflation rate climbed to 7 percent, the highest in 30 years.
description: Household budgets are squeezed as wage increases are not keeping pace with rising prices.
content: In Britain, several pieces of dispiriting economic news arrived this week: Prices are rising at their fastest pace in 30 years, wages adjusted for inflation fell the most in nearly eight years and the economy hardly grew in February.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Blaming Trump, Jan. 6 Suspect Says He Fell Down a ‘Rabbit Hole’ of Lies
description: Dustin Thompson, an unemployed exterminator from Ohio, was the first defendant tried in the Capitol attack to offer a Trump-made-me-do-it defense before a jury.
content: WASHINGTON — Dustin Thompson’s trip down what he called “the rabbit hole” of election misinformation began eight months before a single vote was cast in 2020. It ended inside the United States Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, where he was part of the mob of Trump supporters that stormed inside during Congress’s counting of electoral votes in the worst attack on the building since the War of 1812.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes and Edward Wong
title: U.S. and Ukrainian Groups Pierce Putin’s Propaganda Bubble
description: U.S.-backed news outlets and Ukrainian activists use Cold War techniques and high-tech tactics to get news about the war to Russians.
content: WASHINGTON — Using a mix of high-tech and Cold War tactics, Ukrainian activists and Western institutions have begun to pierce the propaganda bubble in Russia, circulating information about the Ukraine war among Russian citizens to sow doubt about the Kremlin’s accounts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Bulik
title: Cruxy O’Connor and the Central Park Ambush
description: One hundred years ago this week, the British spy was caught in what appears to be the Irish Republican Army’s only authorized attack on American soil.
content: It was a few minutes to 8 o’clock on the evening of April 13, 1922. When Patrick Joseph O’Connor came down the steps of his apartment building on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, three of the Irish Republican Army’s top gunmen were lying in wait.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: How to Find a Mental Health App That Works for You
description: There are thousands of apps that claim to promote mental well-being, but not all of them are safe or effective.
content: With therapists in high demand and long waiting lists that make it challenging to find a provider, using a mental health app might seem like a tempting and relatively inexpensive way to get help.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Are You Reluctant to Get a Covid Booster?
description: Share your story with The New York Times.
content: Less than half of vaccinated Americans who are eligible for a Covid booster have gotten one, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee and Camille Elemia
title: The Philippines Toppled One Marcos. Now His Son May Become President.
description: Ferdinand Marcos Jr. has spent his political career trying to rehabilitate the family name. As the front-runner in the upcoming election, he may finally succeed.
content: MANILA — They bopped along to the beat of a martial law anthem updated into a pop tune. They cheered when an A-list celebrity proclaimed that the spirit of Ferdinand E. Marcos, the former dictator, was alive. And when Mr. Marcos’s son and namesake held up the peace sign made popular by his father a generation ago, the shrieking crowds mirrored it in return.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Megill and Nimmo Get Mets Back on Track With Win
description: The win snapped a two-game losing streak for the Mets. The Reds president, meanwhile, had to apologize for some remarks.
content: PHILADELPHIA — Tylor Megill delivered his second straight scoreless start for the Mets, Brandon Nimmo homered and the Mets beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 2-0, on Tuesday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: The U.S. has expanded intelligence sharing with Ukraine about Russian troops in the Donbas region.
description: Western officials say they expect the Kremlin to mount a major offensive in the Donbas, where Russian-backed separatists have been fighting Ukrainian forces for years.
content: The United States has increased the flow of intelligence to Ukraine about Russian forces in the Donbas and Crimea, as Kyiv’s military forces prepare to defend against a renewed offensive by Moscow in the country’s east, American officials said Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser and Colin Moynihan
title: Cuba Gooding Jr. Pleads Guilty to Forcible Touching
description: The actor must complete six more months of treatment with no new arrests under his plea deal.
content: The actor Cuba Gooding Jr., who had been accused by more than 20 women of groping or forcibly kissing them in encounters that dated back more than two decades, pleaded guilty in Manhattan on Wednesday to one count of forcible touching.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Modern Love Podcast: First Love Mixtape, Side B
description: Listeners from around the world shared their teenage anthems. From Nat King Cole to One Direction, these are the songs that filled their adolescent hearts with longing and passion.
content: When we asked this question at the start of the season, the responses came pouring in. We heard from present-day teens streaming their anthems on repeat, and we heard from listeners who have been with their partners for over 50 years. There were stories of jazz and rap, adrenaline rushes and loneliness, and many lessons in matters of the heart. (“Don’t let your friends choose your boyfriends,” Amy from St. Louis said.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: U.K. May Send Asylum Seekers to Rwanda for Processing
description: The details of the plan will be made public on Thursday, but local news media have reported it may include shipping immigrants to the African country.
content: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s office said he would announce a migration partnership with Rwanda on Thursday, prompting speculation that the deal will include sending migrants arriving in Britain to the African country for processing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: Le Pen Backs NATO-Russia Reconciliation and Reduced French Role in Alliance
description: Marine Le Pen, the far-right candidate for the French presidency, offered a worldview reminiscent of the Trump presidency. “No submission to an American protectorate on European soil,” she said.
content: PARIS — Rejecting a “herd-like conformity” with the Biden administration, Marine Le Pen, the French far-right candidate for the presidency, said Wednesday that France would quit NATO’s integrated military command if she were elected and would seek for the alliance “a strategic rapprochement” with Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: ‘Closest one to him was me,’ said one of the victims of the shooting.
description: Hourari Benkada, 27, said he was sitting next to the man who carried out an attack on the subway in Brooklyn Tuesday morning. He ended up getting shot in the back of the knee.
content: Hourari Benkada, 27, said he was sitting next to the man who carried out an attack on the subway in Brooklyn Tuesday morning. He ended up getting shot in the back of the knee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: ‘To My Girls,’ a Toast to Millennial ‘Instagays’
description: Put three gay frenemies in a Palm Springs Airbnb and what happens? In JC Lee’s new comedy, not enough.
content: They don’t seem to like one another very much, these three gay besties weekending together at a tacky Airbnb in Palm Springs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich, Ashley Southall, Ali Watkins and Kirsten Noyes
title: Sister of suspect in Brooklyn subway shooting says ‘he’s been on his own his whole life.’
description: Frank R. James, whom the police apprehended in connection with the attack on Tuesday, was born in the Bronx but spent his life moving from city to city, his sister said.
content: Even as Frank R. James, the 62-year-old man suspected by the police of opening fire in a crowded subway car, was taken into custody in the early afternoon on Wednesday, new details about his troubled life began to emerge, including a criminal history in at least two states.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland
title: The Biden administration extends the national Covid public health emergency for another 90 days.
description: The emergency declaration, which enables free testing and eases Medicaid eligibility, among other provisions, will now extend at least until mid-July.
content: The Biden administration extended the U.S. coronavirus public health emergency, now more than two years old, for another 90 days on Wednesday. The move will maintain a range of health benefits received by some of the most vulnerable Americans during the pandemic, including access to coronavirus tests and telehealth services.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: The Ukrainian Refugee Crisis Is a Women’s Crisis
description: A wave of displaced women and children into Poland is forcing the country to address its lack of protections for working women.
content: ZABKI, Poland — If there is one thing you should understand about the Ukrainian refugee crisis in Poland, it is this: Approximately 90 percent of the displaced are women and children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabelia Herrera
title: Tokischa, Latin Music’s Newest Rebel, Isn’t Holding Back
description: The gleefully raunchy Dominican rapper, who’s collaborated with J Balvin and Rosalía, has been hailed as an iconoclast. Her own goal is simple: Speaking her truth.
content: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic — On a mid-March evening here in the capital, a crowd of hundreds of festivalgoers wearing fairy wings, rhinestones and rainbow face paint began to chant. “Po-po-la!” they shouted, deploying the local slang for vagina. The scene resembled the summoning of a cult leader, and the Dominican firebrand Tokischa, a rapper known for her prurient lyrics and high-profile collaborations, emerged onstage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: Justice Dept. Moves to Curb Police Abuses in Washington, D.C., and Massachusetts
description: The changes come as the Biden administration has struggled to make meaningful progress on a vow to crack down on police abuses.
content: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department took steps on Wednesday to overhaul policing practices in Washington, D.C., and Springfield, Mass., such as how and when to use force, as President Biden works to fulfill his campaign promise to curb police abuses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Weise
title: Amazon adds a fuel and inflation surcharge to the fees it charges to sellers.
description: The new surcharge is in addition to fee increases for sellers in November that went into effect in January.
content: Facing rising costs, Amazon said on Wednesday that it was adding its first “fuel and inflation surcharge” to the fees it charges sellers whose inventory it warehouses and delivers to customers, according to an announcement on its website.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Starbucks chief talks of possible benefits for nonunionized employees.
description: Experts said the comments raised questions about whether the company was seeking to discriminate against unionized employees.
content: Starbucks’s interim chief executive, Howard Schultz, told a weekly meeting of store managers on Monday that benefits he was considering expanding for nonunion employees would not immediately apply to the company’s newly unionized workers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: North Carolina Drops Mark Meadows From Voter Roll Amid Fraud Inquiry
description: The state is investigating whether Mr. Meadows cast a legal vote in 2020, after reports questioned if he lived at the address listed on his voter registration.
content: Mark Meadows, a former chief of staff in the Trump White House, has been removed from the voter rolls in North Carolina as officials investigate whether he fraudulently registered to vote and cast a ballot in the state during the 2020 presidential election, according to a local election official.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: Several cities are boosting security on their subways.
description: Multiple East Coast cities are increasing security on their subway systems following a shooting on a train in Brooklyn on Tuesday.
content: Multiple East Coast cities are increasing security on their subway systems following a shooting on a train in Brooklyn on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora, Erika Solomon and Carlotta Gall
title: ‘Clear Patterns’ of Russian Rights Abuses Found in Ukraine, Report Says
description: Momentum is building to try to bring war crimes charges tied to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
content: Investigators from almost a dozen countries combed bombed-out towns and freshly dug graves in Ukraine on Wednesday for evidence of war crimes, and a wide-ranging investigation by an international security organization detailed what it said were “clear patterns” of human rights violations by Russian forces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz and Adam Satariano
title: Russian Tech Industry Faces ‘Brain Drain’ as Workers Flee
description: Since their country invaded Ukraine, Russian tech workers have left by the thousands. They appear intent on rebuilding their lives and businesses in other countries.
content: In early March, days after Russia invaded Ukraine and began cracking down on dissent at home, Konstantin Siniushin, a venture capitalist in Riga, Latvia, helped charter two planes out of Russia to help people flee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: ‘Seek and Hide’ Grapples With the Complexity of the Right to Privacy
description: The law professor Amy Gajda writes about the tug of war between the right to know and the right to be let alone.
content: In her wry and fascinating new book, “Seek and Hide,” Amy Gajda traces the history of the right to privacy and its (understandably fraught) relationship in the United States with the First Amendment. English common law includes the concept of “truthful libel” — the notion that anything harmful to a person’s reputation, even if factually accurate, could be treated as a punishable offense.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Hamby, Walt Bogdanich, Michael Forsythe and Jennifer Valentino-DeVries
title: McKinsey Opened a Door in Its Firewall Between Pharma Clients and Regulators
description: The firm let consultants advise both drugmakers and their government overseers, internal records show. “Who we know and what we know” was part of their pitch.
content: Jeff Smith, a partner with the influential consulting firm McKinsey & Company, accepted a highly sensitive assignment in December 2017. The opioid manufacturer Purdue Pharma, beleaguered and in financial trouble, wanted to revamp its business, and an executive there sought out Dr. Smith.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Murphy
title: Masks Stay On: C.D.C. Keeps the Mandate on Planes
description: Despite pressure from airlines and industry groups, the Biden administration extended the requirement to wear masks while traveling on public transportation through May 3.
content: Despite great pressure from airlines, the hospitality industry and Republican lawmakers to lift the rule requiring masks on planes and other public transportation, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention extended the federal transportation mask requirement for two weeks on Wednesday, five days before it was set to expire. The mask mandate now expires May 3, if it is not extended yet again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: A ‘Silent Victim’: How Nature Becomes a Casualty of War
description: Research on past conflicts suggests that the war in Ukraine could have a profound environmental impact.
content: The Black Sea Biosphere Reserve, on the southern coast of Ukraine, is a haven for migrating birds. More than 120,000 birds spend the winter flitting about its shores, and a multicolored spectrum of rare species — the white-tailed eagle, red-breasted merganser and black-winged stilt, to name just a few — nest among its protected waters and wetlands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By German Lopez
title: Inflation’s 40-Year High
description: We look at why prices might ease — and why they might not.
content: The overall cost of gas, food and other everyday items is increasing at its fastest rate in more than 40 years. And experts cannot say with confidence whether price increases will speed up or slow down in the coming months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos, Jeffery C. Mays and William K. Rashbaum
title: The Deep-Pocketed Developer Who Helped Take Down the Lieutenant Governor
description: Gerald Migdol, a Harlem developer, became the linchpin in a federal investigation that led to the indictment and resignation of Lt. Gov. Brian Benjamin.
content: For the Harlem real estate developer Gerald Migdol, the annual charity golf outing in Westchester County was a showcase to display his generosity. Politicians, business associates and minor celebrities circled the private links, helping his small foundation pay for backpacks and Thanksgiving turkeys distributed to needy families.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes and Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Announces $800 Million in Military Assistance for Ukraine
description: The United States will also step up intelligence sharing as Russia appears to be preparing an offensive in eastern Ukraine.
content: WASHINGTON — The United States will send an additional $800 million worth of military and other security aid to Ukraine and step up intelligence sharing, American officials announced on Wednesday, as Russian forces appeared to be preparing for a new offensive in the country’s east.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William Grimes
title: Michel Bouquet, Award-Winning French Actor, Dies at 96
description: One of his country’s great theater performers, he went on to appear in more than 100 films playing ordinary men whose surface blandness masked complex lives.
content: Michel Bouquet, a French actor whose talent for suggesting passion and turmoil beneath a bland, middle-class facade made him a favorite of New Wave directors, died on Wednesday in Paris. He was 96.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich, Ashley Southall, Ali Watkins and Kirsten Noyes
title: Suspect Drifted From City to City as His Videos Hinted at Violence
description: Interviews, arrest records and hours of his own words on YouTube paint an incomplete but troubling picture of Frank James, who was arrested in Tuesday’s subway shooting.
content: Buried in a sea of disturbing videos that Frank R. James posted on YouTube in recent weeks was a plan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu
title: Substack’s Growth Spurt Brings Growing Pains
description: The publishing platform’s founders want Substack to be an “alternate universe on the internet.” But it faces copycat rivals, an exodus by writers and a need to move beyond newsletters.
content: There are things that the newsletter writer Kirsten Han misses about Substack. They just aren’t enough to outweigh the downsides.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Schulten
title: What Are the Most Memorable Works of Visual Art You’ve Ever Seen?
description: Whether experienced in a museum, on a city street, via social media, in a classroom or anywhere else, what paintings, sculptures, photos, illustrations or other works of visual art have most affected you?
content: Are you attracted to visual art? Do you go to exhibits? Stop on the street to admire murals, graffiti or public sculpture? Scroll through artistic photos on social media? Or even make your own?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: Texas Governor Offers Deal to End Snarled Traffic at Border
description: Gov. Greg Abbott said the state police would no longer inspect all trucks coming from one Mexican state after officials there agreed to increase border security.
content: HOUSTON — Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas said on Wednesday that days of snarled traffic on the border, caused by new safety inspections he ordered last week, were part of a concerted effort to force Mexican officials to do more to stop the flow of migrants into the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kat Chow
title: Mourning Songs for Lives, and Art, That Could Have Been
description: Memoirs by Samantha Hunt, Natalie Hodges and Ashley Marie Farmer transform grief into literature.
content: Samantha ﻿Hunt’s memoir, THE UNWRITTEN BOOK: An Investigation (366 pp., Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $27), is a provocative meditation on family and haunting. “The long view of existence … is not the story I most often focus on,” she writes, laying the foundation for her first nonfiction book (after three novels and a story collection, “The Dark Dark”). “Rather, I look for and love the drama in the small details particular to one person, the crooked tooth, the bitten nails, the hidden suffering.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: That’s Good Thinking!
description: Rebecca Goldstein’s puzzle challenges you to the best of three.
content: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Although I’ve been solving for many, many years, I’m still delighted when a constructor comes up with a totally original twist on a theme concept that has been seen before. These clever innovations may make you exclaim, “That’s good thinking!” (or, if you’re also a crossword constructor, “Why didn’t I think of that!?”).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Delta Air Lines sees a turn toward profit, and carriers’ shares soar.
description: Delta said its March operations were profitable, despite rising fuel costs. It reported a first-quarter loss, but revenue exceeded its forecast.
content: Delta Air Lines reported a quarterly loss on Wednesday as thriving ticket sales were offset by high fuel prices. But it said that its March operations were profitable and that it had been able to pass some of the higher cost of fuel along to customers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: A Subway Attack That Shook New York City
description: The gunman who injured 23 in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, escaped, but the police identified a person of interest.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. Two stories will dominate the conversation today: the attack in the subway that left at least 23 people injured, 10 from gunfire, and the resignation of Lt. Gov. Brian Benjamin, hours after he was arrested on corruption charges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Luke Broadwater
title: Two Trump White House Lawyers Meet With Jan. 6 Investigators
description: Pat A. Cipollone, the former White House counsel, and Patrick F. Philbin, who was his deputy, met separately with the panel after the former president authorized them to do so.
content: Two of former President Donald J. Trump’s top White House lawyers met on Wednesday with the House committee investigating the Capitol attack, after Mr. Trump authorized them to engage with the panel, according to a person familiar with the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Li Yuan
title: China’s ‘Zero Covid’ Mess Proves Autocracy Hurts Everyone
description: The fear in China is that the strict coronavirus policy has become another Mao-style political campaign with devastating effects.
content: Long before the “zero Covid” policy, China had a “zero sparrow” policy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: British territory freezes $7 billion in assets believed to be tied to Roman Abramovich.
description: Jersey, an island in the English Channel, froze assets believed to be linked to the Russian oligarch, on whom Britain imposed sanctions after Russia invaded Ukraine.
content: The economic vise is tightening around Roman Abramovich, whose assets were targeted by British authorities more than a month ago as part of the West’s sanctions on Russian oligarchs after the invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Shirley Spork, Teaching Pro and a Founder of the L.P.G.A., Dies at 94
description: She was one of 13 who started the Ladies Professional Golf Association in 1950, though her legacy lay in tutoring countless women, from duffers to pros.
content: Shirley Spork, one of the most prominent teaching pros in women’s golf and one of the last survivors among the 13 women who founded the Ladies Professional Golf Association in 1950, died on Tuesday at her home in Palm Springs, Calif. She was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons and Jeffery C. Mays
title: Mayor Eric Adams says the ‘person of interest’ in Brooklyn subway shooting is now a suspect.
description: Mayor Eric Adams said on Wednesday morning that the man who the police had identified as a “person of interest” in the mass shooting on the subway in Brooklyn the day before was now considered a suspect.
content: Mayor Eric Adams said on Wednesday morning that the man who the police had identified as a “person of interest” in the mass shooting on the subway in Brooklyn the day before was now considered a suspect.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: Man Who Stole Dozens of Golf Carts Is Sentenced to 2 Years in Prison
description: For four years, the man, Nathan Rodney Nelson, 46, acted at night, stealing carts from golf courses and driving them to a getaway vehicle, prosecutors said. Then his phone number gave him away.
content: A man who admitted to stealing or trying to steal 84 golf carts across several states in an effort to solve his financial troubles was sentenced on Tuesday to two years in prison, the authorities in North Dakota said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Fortuitous Finds
description: What are the most valuable, interesting or memorable things you’ve ever found, whether on the street or anywhere else?
content: A recent Times article explains that “New York City curbs are awash in furniture left behind by people who are moving, who died, or who are simply fickle.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Weekly Accessible Learning Activities: Yawning, Walking, Mowing the Lawn
description: Each week we spotlight five student activities created for a broad range of learners based on reporting in The New York Times.
content: Each Wednesday we shine a spotlight on five student activities that support a broad range of learners. In this week’s roundup of accessible activities, we invite students to learn about yawning, share how they feel about walking, watch a film about the American lawn, make observations about a photograph and reflect on forgiveness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Gutierrez
title: More Than 120 Dead After Tropical Storm Hits the Philippines
description: The first such storm of the year caused widespread flooding and landslides in the central part of the country.
content: MANILA — Rescue workers battled intermittent heavy rain to reach many people still missing Wednesday, three days after Tropical Storm Megi pummeled the country, causing widespread landslides and flooding in the central Philippines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Arming Ukraine
description: The U.S. will send an additional $800 million worth of weapons and other security aid to Ukraine.
content: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Israel’s Oldest Museum Takes a New Look at Israeli Art
description: For decades, museums presented Israeli art as a companion to the country’s history. The Tel Aviv Museum of Art breaks away from that approach — with surprising results.
content: TEL AVIV — When the Tel Aviv Museum of Art’s permanent collection of Israeli art reopened in February, the first work visitors saw wasn’t even Israeli. It was a bust by a Scottish Jewish artist, Benno Schotz, who spent most of his life in Glasgow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: Let Him Entertain You: Billy Crystal Returns to Broadway
description: The comedian is starring in “Mr. Saturday Night,” a musical version of his 1992 movie about an aging performer who won’t accept that his time in the spotlight is up.
content: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: F.D.R. Speeches and Alicia Keys Album Added to National Recording Registry
description: A hit by the band Journey, radio accounts of the 9/11 attacks, “Buena Vista Social Club” and a recording of Hank Aaron’s 715th home run also made the registry.
content: Franklin D. Roosevelt’s speech about “a date which will live in infamy.” The rock band Journey’s song about “a small-town girl livin’ in a lonely world” who takes a midnight train going anywhere. And firsthand descriptions of the 2001 attacks on the World Trade Center.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg and Nancy Wartik
title: 500 Million Recorded Cases?
description: The real number of global infections is likely to be much, much larger.
content: The pandemic, now in its third year, has reached a monumental scale across the world. Countries have now logged 500 million confirmed cases of Covid-19, including more than 200 million this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Imbler
title: Shriek! Slap! Pow! The Small Bat Wins.
description: In this video of a bat fight, is the tiny one a bully, or is it just meting out justice up the food chain?
content: One morning in the Panamanian rainforest, a small fruit bat sized up his competition. The odds did not appear to be in his favor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins
title: Did Someone Say Orgy? Your Spring Politics Quiz.
description: Let’s see how much you remember.
content: Let’s see how much you remember.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: Florida’s Manatee Culture
description: The iconic Florida manatee faces the threat of mass starvation. With it, a piece of the state’s identity is at risk.
content: The iconic Florida manatee faces the threat of mass starvation. With it, a piece of the state’s identity is at risk.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Quiet Spot in Grenada for $1.95 Million
description: This two-bedroom farm-style house on the coast of Carriacou, an island in the Caribbean nation of Grenada, is for sale for $1.95 million.
content: This two-bedroom farm-style house on the coast of Carriacou, an island in the Caribbean nation of Grenada, is for sale for $1.95 million.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What You Get for $2.2 Million
description: A Nashville Victorian owned by an HGTV host; a Key West, Fla., house where the writer John Dos Passos once lived; and a log cabin in East Durham, N.Y.
content: A Nashville Victorian owned by an HGTV host; a Key West, Fla., house where the writer John Dos Passos once lived; and a log cabin in East Durham, N.Y.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Living In ... Woodbridge, Conn.
description: This ‘suburban community in a country setting’ is just a 20-minute commute from Yale University, other educational institutions and biotech companies.
content: This ‘suburban community in a country setting’ is just a 20-minute commute from Yale University, other educational institutions and biotech companies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Tropical Storm Leaves Dozens Dead or Missing in the Philippines
description: Nearly 30 people remained missing three days after Tropical Storm Megi hit the central Philippines, triggering deadly landslides and flooding.
content: Nearly 30 people remained missing three days after Tropical Storm Megi hit the central Philippines, triggering deadly landslides and flooding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Finland and Sweden to Consider Joining NATO
description: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has pushed Sweden and Finland to seriously weigh applying for membership to the alliance.
content: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has pushed Sweden and Finland to seriously weigh applying for membership to the alliance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chevaz Clarke-Williams and Rex Sakamoto
title: Gunman at Large After New York Subway Shooting
description: Police are searching for a man who opened fire in a subway train in Brooklyn and shot at least 10 people.
content: Police are searching for a man who opened fire in a subway train in Brooklyn and shot at least 10 people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan DiTrolio
title: The Host of ‘Modern Love’ Opens Up About Helping Guests Open Up
description: In January, Anna Martin became the voice of the popular podcast. She shares how she holds empathetic interviews.
content: Modern Love explores all types of imperfect, messy and totally worth-it love: Not just the romantic kind, but the familial, the platonic and the kind you have for yourself.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: April 13, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, April 13, 2022.
content: An article on Tuesday about tensions at Twitter after Elon Musk became the company’s largest shareholder described incorrectly the role of Rich Greenfield. He is an analyst for the research firm LightShed Partners, not the venture capital investment fund LightShed Ventures.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Fighting the Latest Efforts to Outlaw Abortion
description: Readers discuss moves to ban abortion pills and lament passage of an Oklahoma anti-abortion bill. Also: Saving baseball; sex and manners; Covid vaccines.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: April 14, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, April 14, 2022.
content: An article on Friday about key facts concerning France’s presidential election referred imprecisely to the election of 1965. That was the first time that a president was elected in a direct ballot; it was not the case that a candidate was elected without a runoff. That has not happened yet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: More Holiday Prep!
description: Readers are looking for recipes for Passover, Easter and Ramadan, and we have lots of options.
content: Good morning. We’re in another holiday chute this week, with Passover coming on Friday night, Easter on Sunday and Ramadan ongoing. My inbox is flooding with requests for recipes.
source.name: The New York Times
